EmployerOrg.EmployerOrgName: The City College of New York

PositionHistory.Title: Director, CUNY Institute for Urban Systems
Distinguished Professor of Civil Engineering
PositionHistory.Description: Dr. Paaswell's scholarly focus includes transit system budgeting and finance, including operating and capital budgets transit investment strategies and issues of transit system governance. Highlights of his activities and publications are listed further in this document. He remains active with the various Centers he has led.

PositionHistory.Title: Interim President / Interim President of City College
PositionHistory.Description: Dr. Paaswell was the chief executive of the flagship institution of CUNY. The College is a comprehensive teaching, research, and service institution akin to small university. The College is a comprehensive teaching, research, and service institution with 16,000 students, professional schools in architecture, biomedical education, education and engineering, a College of Liberal Arts and Science and an annual budget of over $230 million. During his tenure Dr. Paaswell raised the intellectual profile of the College in the eyes of other academicians and the press by engaging outstanding scholars, convening national symposia in physics and public transportation and through other activities that underscored the academic excellence of the institution. He re-invigorated a faculty which was ranked as having the lowest in morale in the CUNY network. He further re-focused the administration on its core mission of serving the students and faculty. Other initiatives included taking steps to restructure the collaboration between College's fund-raising offices and generally preparing the College for new leadership. In his related role as President of the City College 21st Century Foundation he worked closely with alumni leaders to raise $29.4 million in gifts for the College. His outreach to elected and local leaders helped pave the way for future partnerships between the College and its Upper Manhattan community. Director, The University Transportation Center The University Transportation Center (UTRC) is one of ten federally designated Regional Centers, and is funded annually at a multi-million dollar level by federal and regional sources. The Center provides and sponsors a series of programs in Research, Education and Training, and Technology Transfer. The 12 academic institutions in New York, New Jersey and Puerto Rico that comprise the Center are the City University of New York, Columbia University, Cornell University, New Jersey Institute of Technology, New York University, Polytechnic Institute of NYU, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Rowan University, Rutgers University, State University of New York, Stevens Institute of Technology, and the University of Puerto Rico - MayagÃ¼ez. Under Dr. Paaswell, UTRC became a major resource on public transportation issues for the region and nation. He has improved management, budgeting and reporting, participation by regional organizations, and inter-university research and training efforts with the impact of gaining national and international recognition for the Center. He has served in a leadership capacity among national Center Directors, with responsibility for strategic planning of the national program. Director, The CUNY Institute for Urban Systems The CUNY Institute for Urban Systems is a multi-campus Institute addressing infrastructure issues that incorporate new technologies, institutional forms and change and issues of financing. It is supported by City University of New York and external grants. It houses a Building Performance Lab sponsored by the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority.

PositionHistory.Title: Professor
PositionHistory.Description: developed program and courses transportation policy developed research program. As Consultant worked for a large number of clients on projects including employment access air terminal geometry light rail transit design transit mall design and planning.

PositionHistory.Title: Executive Director
PositionHistory.Description: The Chicago Transit Authority (CTA) is North America's second largest transit system providing two million trips per day on both extensive bus and rail networks. With 13,000 employees and an approximately $1 billion annual operating and capital budget. CTA operates in a difficult political and urban environment. The Executive Director reports directly to the Chairman of a seven-member appointed Board is the Chief Executive Officer and responsible for the day to day operations of the Authority. The Executive Director is responsible for carrying out the policies of the Board. He was nominated by the Mayor of Chicago and appointed by the CTA Board. During his tenure Dr. Paaswell reformed and redirected a highly complex agency operating in a difficult and constraining external environment. Representative achievements include: Professionalization of management * Application of strategic approaches to problem solving * Development of mission and goal statement. * Structuring and defining a strategic plan Instituted program-based budgeting together with clarified program objectives and utilization of the budget a strategic planning process * Restructured the procurement and capital construction processes * Development of fleet management plans * Creation of an openness of the agency to the public with increased information provided public and business groups. * Modernization of computer system and initiation of a micro-computer working environment. Development of innovate and aggressive Affirmative Action and DBE/MBE programs.

PositionHistory.Title: Director / The Director of the Center
PositionHistory.Description: The Urban Transportation Center is a major research center at the, reported to the Vice Chancellor of the University and had the responsibility to develop the center into a major National Center from its inception. During the period of Paaswell leadership, he attracted more than twenty research grants, and formed a working group of twenty faculty and a research staff of more than forty graduate and undergraduate students to work on significant regional and national transportation programs. These were carried out for both public and private clients. Among the more significant studies were: privatization of handicapped transit for CTA, value study of Milwaukee Road to establish system value organization of a regional conference to provide input to Regional Transportation Authority Act, analysis of transportation to health care for teenage mothers, access to employment by urban residents, training and modeling behavior of freight locomotive engineers, and development of a cooperative program with China.. The Center brought a rigorous, approach of academic-based group talent to bear on difficult regional transportation problems.

Paaswell served on the TRB/USDOT Task Force that defined the University Transportation Centers Program and was responsible for the oversight of the first competition.

TCRP is a multi-million dollar federally funded program administered by TRB and APTA, developed to conduct research for the Transit Industry.

Author of two books, eleven book chapters, and over 150 technical publications and reports
contributor of articles to World Book Encyclopedia.
Listed in "Who's Who in the World, "Who's Who in America", "Who's Who in Engineering", "Who's Who in Finance and Industry."
Principal Investigator or co-investigator for over 80 sponsored research grants with a total value of over $60M.
This project examines application of evolving concepts of growth limits, sustainability to NYC. ($25k)
Long Island Transportation Intermodal Transfer Facility - A major study in response to a gubernatorial request to solve a problem of locating a rail-truck freight transfer facility on Long Island.
The study has made recommendations that will change the position of rail freight in NY State.
I278 Freight Corridor Study - for NYSDOT, an assessment of necessary investments to maximize the impact of the proposed NY-NJ rail freight tunnel. (1.5 m)

Impacts of Rail Transit Investments - pioneering study for the Partnership of the City of NY to evaluate the transportation and economic development impacts of 12 propsed infrastructure investments post Sept.

This project, an analysis of the impacts of transportation investments in Northern New Jersey on economic development was in response to the governor's challenge for innovative research to guide investment policy.
It is a three year project by New Jersey Department of Transportation. ($250, k)
Analysis of Capital Cost Elements for Light Rail Transit - Federal Transit Administration - 2005 Detailed analysis of factors driving capital project cost escalation
Impacts of Deferred Investments on Capital and Operating budgets, report for the NY MTA, 2004
Development of major training initiative concerning integration of new technologies into transit systems. ($75k)
Paaswell was asked by New York City Transit to oversee and develop a process to have labor and management agree on work hours for major bus maintenance tasks (a first in the transit industry).
He formed a team with Industrial Engineers to establish a protocol for measurement and time determination that was accepted by both labor and management.
Over 70 items have been codified to date in this historic initiative.
The estimated savings form the first set of tasks was $11 million per year.
The project has been funded at $125 thousand.
Paaswell was asked by NYCDOT to Direct a study examining Routes and Ridership of the Franchise Bus Services:
The Study examined methods of verifying ridership and approaches to Route Rationalization.
